name: soybean, feed production | soybean, feed | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/13785/documentation

The inventory refers to 1 kg processed feedstuff (fresh weight). This dataset has been created as a proxy for roasted soybeans used in swine diet in Québec.

The dataset starts with the reception of feedstuff at the processing centre.

The activities end with the storage of the feed mixes. The inventory includes processing feedstuff (crushing or milling, heat treatment, dosing, mixing squeezing and pelleting) and the storage of the feed mixes. It also includes water use and wastewater treatment, the transformation and use of land related to the storage buildings. No process emissions (e.g. dust and particulate matter) were included except heat waste from the use of electricity. Packaging is not included.
category: C:Manufacturing/10:Manufacture of food products/108:Manufacture of prepared animal feeds/1080:Manufacture of prepared animal feeds

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Years of the publications of the main sources
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset is extrapolated from an original dataset covering the geography of Switzerland.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This dataset is extrapolated from an original dataset which technology refers to non expanded feedstuff from protein peas and broad beans.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset originates from an dataset covering the geography CH and the technology of Swiss Integrated Production (SIP), Uncertainty and production volume have been adjusted. The technology of grain processing can be assumed the same for conventional grain as for SIP grain, hence no change is made to the technology-related uncertainty index. Note that properties of the reference product (carbon and water contents) are the same as the input grain, as it is also the case for the original dataset. No loss of grain is considered, due to lack of comprehensive data.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data based on literature, trade statistics and information from feedstuff processing enterprises.

exchanges.description: Processed soybeans used for animal feed (e.g. swine diet). This is not protein meal as no oil extraction is involved.

flow.name: soybean, feed
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/10:Manufacture of food products/108:Manufacture of prepared animal feeds/1080:Manufacture of prepared animal feeds

exchanges.description: Emission calculated from tap water input and wastewater generation for water balance.

Literature Value. Salzgeber & Lörcher (1996) give the total energy and water consumption of a mill processing about 30,000 tonnes of cereals per year. The mill consumes 1800 m3 water and produces 1200 m3 wastewater per year. Water consumption and wastewater output was completed from Salzgeber and Lörcher (1996), namely 56 litres tap water and 38 litres wastewater per tonne of feedstuff produced.

defaultProvider.category: E:Water supply; sewerage, waste management and remediation activities/36:Water collection, treatment and supply/360:Water collection, treatment and supply/3600:Water collection, treatment and supply

exchanges.description: Estimation. Corresponds to land use Transformation*2 years (the length of the construction phase is 2 years).

Estimation. The typical storage capacity of the cereal silo found in some feed processing centres in Switzerland is 10,000 tonnes, with an effective storage volume of about 80% of the building volume. With an average grain specific weight of 750 kg/m3, this gives a building volume of about 16,650 m3. Assuming that these feed processing centres process 25,000 tonnes of grain per year, the cereals will be stored for about three months before being processed. 
The largest feed processing centre in Switzerland (UFA-Biblis) has a feedstuff storage compound of 29,440 m3 (80 m length * 23 m * 16 m height) with an effective storage capacity of 4,140 tonnes (5520 palettes of 750 kg), or about 150 kg/m3 (UFA 2002). This centre processes 275,000 tonnes of concentrate feeds yearly. After processing, the feedstuff must therefore be stored for approx. one week in the processing centre before being sent to the regional storehouse.
The average length of storage of the raw materials is set at 3 months in the calculations. The storage volume required was estimated as 1.7 m3/tonne of raw material (grain specific weight 750 kg/m3 and 80% of the building volume used for storage). The lifetime of the storage silo was assumed to be 50 years, the length of the construction phase 2 years. Land use was estimated from the height of Biblis’s storage silo (UFA 2002). Taking the height of 16 m, the area used is 0.1 m2/tonne of feedstuff for 3 months.

exchanges.description: Estimation. Corresponds to occupation industrial area/50 years (the lifetime of the storage silo was assumed to be 50 years).

Grain input for feed production. Due to lack of representative data, no loss is considered. Since Québec is a net exporter of soybean (production higher than domestic demand), a direct link to Quebec soybean production is considered as long as a regional market is not available (source: Monographie du secteur des grains au Québec, 2013.
https://www.mapaq.gouv.qc.ca/fr/Publications/Monographiegrain.pdf)

exchanges.description: Estimation. Corresponds to  0.2m2/tonne (because the total area occupied as “industrial area” was estimated as twice as high, namely 0.2 m2/tonne) multiplied by 3 months (because the average length of storage of the raw materials is set at 3 months in the calculations).
Estimation. Corresponds to occupation industrial area/50 years (the lifetime of the storage silo was assumed to be 50 years).

Literature Value. See ecoinvent dataset "protein pea, feed production, Swiss integrated production" for details.
Cederberg C. (1998) Life cycle assessment of milk production. A comparison of conventional and organic farming. The Swedish Institute for Food and Biotechnology. SIK-Rapport 1998 No. 643, 86 p.
Salzgeber Ch. & Lörcher M. (1996) Produktökobilanz Brot unter verschiedenen Landbaubedingungen. In: Umweltverträgliche Pflanzenproduktion: Indikatoren, Bilanzierungsansätze und ihre Einbindung in Ökobilanzen. 11-12 July 1996, Wittenberg, 249-269.
Higler J., Kühl R., Fries R., Pfeffer E. & Schulze Lammers P. (1997) Oekonomische und energetische Bewertung einer umweltgerechten Verwertung von Koppelprodukten der Ernährungsbranche und sonstigen organischen Reststoffen in der Landwirtschaft sowie Ansätze zur Entwicklung eines Recyclingkonzeptes. Forschungsberichte / Lehr- und Forschungsschwerpunkt "Umweltverträgliche und Standortgerechte Landwirtschaft" an der Landwirtschaftlichen Fakultät der Rheinischen Friedrich-Wilhelms-Universität 1364765. Bonn Institut für Landwirtschaftliche Betriebslehre.

exchanges.description:
Literature Value. According to Cederberg (1998) for protein mixes from legumes such as “protein peas” and “broad beans” the energy usage is 70% of the expanded feedstuff value of InfoMil (1996) since this is not expanded. This resulted into 25 kWh electricity electricity per tonne of feedstuff.
Cederberg C. (1998) Life cycle assessment of milk production. A comparison of conventional and organic farming. The Swedish Institute for Food and Biotechnology. SIK-Rapport 1998 No. 643, 86 p.
